articles.headline: C.I.A. Director Defends Use of Interrogation Tactics, Avoiding Issue of Torture
articles.snippet: John O. Brennan described agency interrogators as “patriots” and pointedly refused to say that brutal methods like waterboarding amounted to torture.
articles.abstract: John O. Brennan described agency interrogators as “patriots” and pointedly refused to say that brutal methods like waterboarding amounted to torture.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANGLEY, Va. — John O. Brennan, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, on Thursday strongly defended C.I.A. officers who carried out brutal interrogation tactics against Qaeda suspects, describing agency interrogators as “patriots” and admonishing only those who went “outside the bounds” of Justice Department rules.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: House Narrowly Passes Bill to Avoid Shutdown; $1.1 Trillion in Spending
articles.snippet: The package advanced by a slim margin amid a rancorous debate that reflected the new power held by Republicans and the disarray among Democrats.
articles.abstract: The package advanced by a slim margin amid a rancorous debate that reflected the new power held by Republicans and the disarray among Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House narrowly passed a $1.1 trillion spending package on Thursday that would fund most government operations for the fiscal year after a rancorous debate that reflected the new power held by Republicans and the disarray among Democrats in the aftermath of the midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Misreading the Lessons From Financial Crises
articles.snippet: With the Fed ready to step in at every tipping point, the need to rethink regulation was overlooked.
articles.abstract: With the Fed ready to step in at every tipping point, the need to rethink regulation was overlooked.
articles.lead_paragraph: “There are good crises and there are bad crises. Every crisis breaks a deadlock and sets events in motion. It is either a disaster or an opportunity. A bad crisis is one in which no one has the power to make good use of the opportunity and therefore it ends in disaster. A good crisis is one in which the power and the will to seize the opportunity are in being. Out of such a crisis come solutions.”

articles.headline: The Vanishing Male Worker: How America Fell Behind
articles.snippet: The share of men aged 25 to 54 who are not working has more than tripled since the late 1960s, with many having decided that low-wage jobs will not improve their lives.
articles.abstract: The share of men aged 25 to 54 who are not working has more than tripled since the late 1960s, with many having decided that low-wage jobs will not improve their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Frank Walsh still pays dues to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, but more than four years have passed since his name was called at the union hall where the few available jobs are distributed. Mr. Walsh, his wife and two children live on her part-time income and a small inheritance from his mother, which is running out.

articles.headline: Solar Rises in Malaysia During Trade Wars Over Panels
articles.snippet: As Chinese companies have been hit by American tariffs and European quotas, Malaysia has attracted multinationals.
articles.abstract: As Chinese companies have been hit by American tariffs and European quotas, Malaysia has attracted multinationals.
articles.lead_paragraph: KULIM, Malaysia — Tucked away in this former tin-mining town, past the small farms of banana trees and oil palms, is one of the solar industry’s best-kept secrets.

articles.headline: Furor Over Move to Aid Big Banks in Funding Bill
articles.snippet: An attempt to repeal a measure to ensure that banks trade their riskiest financial instruments without government protection has drawn bipartisan outrage in Congress.
articles.abstract: An attempt to repeal a measure to ensure that banks trade their riskiest financial instruments without government protection has drawn bipartisan outrage in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a 1,600-page, $1.1 trillion spending bill, a provision to roll back an obscure financial regulation became a focal point of uproar as Congress struggled to keep the government funded.

articles.headline: Dogs in Heaven? Pope Francis Leaves Pearly Gates Open
articles.snippet: Pope Francis’ remarks to a distraught little boy whose dog had died have caused a new debate on whether animals have souls, suffer and go to heaven.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis’ remarks to a distraught little boy whose dog had died have caused a new debate on whether animals have souls, suffer and go to heaven.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has given hope to gays, unmarried couples and advocates of the Big Bang theory. Now, he has endeared himself to dog lovers, animal rights activists and vegans.

articles.headline: Gucci’s Creative and Business Heads Will Step Down
articles.snippet: The Italian fashion house is among luxury brands struggling to cope with an uncertain global economy as tastes change and smaller rivals gain.
articles.abstract: The Italian fashion house is among luxury brands struggling to cope with an uncertain global economy as tastes change and smaller rivals gain.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 93-year-old Gucci brand was long a powerhouse for the luxury group Kering. But in recent years, the Italian fashion house seemed to have lost its way.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: W.T.O. Fails on High-Tech Tariff Deal
articles.snippet: A dispute between China and South Korea scuttled a deal that would have reduced global tariffs on $1 trillion in information technology goods.
articles.abstract: A dispute between China and South Korea scuttled a deal that would have reduced global tariffs on $1 trillion in information technology goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, their faces beaming with self-congratulatory enthusiasm, President Obama and China’s president, Xi Jinping, announced an agreement to drop tariffs on a range of high-technology products, an accord that was supposed to propel far more significant trade talks in the weeks to come.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Paul Mozur
